title: High-Flown Speech
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Its not often that I encourage you to stop and smell the crosswords, because that would just be silly, but todays puzzle by Timothy Polin is worth it.

title: Better Call Saul Season 4, Episode 6 Recap: Disillusionment
description: Is Better Call Saul an extended argument against a career in corporate law? It sure seems like it at times. From the days of Kims tedious document discovery work as a young associate to her growing disillusionment with Mesa Verde, the show can feel like a heartfelt warning from a television writer who regrets a few years in the foxhole at a white-collar firm.

title: Nazi Collaborator or National Hero? A Test for Lithuania
description: SUKIONIAI, Lithuania  For the tiny village of Sukioniai in western Lithuania, the exploits of General Storm, a local anti-Communist hero executed by the Soviet secret police in 1947, have long been a source of pride. The village school is named after him, and his struggles against the Soviet Union are also honored with a memorial carved from stone next to the farm where he was born.

title: Jets Sam Darnold Turns Disaster Into Dominance in Win Over Lions
description: DETROIT  Sam Darnolds slow, lonely walk began on the 25-yard line as pandemonium unfolded behind him. He glanced quickly at the scoreboard. He bowed his head. He cursed. He would not dare remove his helmet.

title: Quotation of the Day: Nazi Collaborator or National Hero? A Test for Lithuania
description: Every family has its ugly things, but they dont talk about them. It is better to stay silent.

Cuomo Bridge enticements to meet a late August deadline to open, including the possibility of absorbing extra costs and reducing their responsibility for potential traffic accidents, according to an internal document obtained by The New York Times.

title: Lasker Awards Given for Work in Genetics, Anesthesia and Promoting Women in Science
description: The Lasker Awards, which are among the nations most prestigious prizes in medicine, were awarded on Tuesday to a Scottish veterinarian who developed the drug propofol, two scientists who discovered the hidden influence of genetic packing material called histones and a researcher who in addition to doing groundbreaking work in RNA biology, paved the way for a new generation of female scientists.

description: Watch a new episode of The Purge on USA and catch Season 7 of Call the Midwife on Netflix.

description: Good Tuesday morning, and welcome to the new On Politics morning briefing. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

title: Word + Quiz: congenital
Do Parrots Know Economics? Kind Of
description: A test of four different species shows they can accurately assign value to food and tokens, swapping lower value items for higher value food.

title: Parrots Think Theyre So Smart. Now Theyre Bartering Tokens for Food.
description: Chalk up another achievement for parrots, with an odd twist that raises questions about whether the experimenters or the birds know best.

title: How Teeth Became Tusks, and Tusks Became Liabilities
description: GORONGOSA NATIONAL PARK, Mozambique  We are flying in a Bat Hawk aircraft  which may be named for a raptor that preys on bats but looks more like a giant, lime-green dragonfly  and my hair, thanks to the open cockpit, has gone full Phyllis Diller.

title: Remembering 9/11
description: The twin beams of the Tribute in Light memorial first lit up the sky over Lower Manhattan on March 11, 2002, six months after the Sept. 11 attacks. Every year at this time, the beams of the memorial return.

title: Are Museums Still Important in the Digital Age?
description: We live in an age when you can virtually visit the Louvre in Paris to see the Mona Lisa or the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York to gaze at the Egyptian Temple of Dendur  all from your phone or desktop. So do museums still matter? Are they worth actually stepping inside to see collections firsthand? And are they worth protecting for the future?

title: Article of the Day: To Anyone Who Thinks Journalists Cant Change the World
description: Before reading the article:

title: Photographing Places Blessed by Nature and Contested by Man
description: Decades of armed conflict between the Colombian government and rebel groups rendered vast swaths of the countrys northwest off-limits to interlopers, who risked being kidnapped, or worse. Those perils have largely vanished after peace accords with the main rebel group, the FARC, removed man-made dangers. But this remote area  thick with vegetation and resources  still has many natural obstacles.

title: Broadways Biggest Debut: King Kong
description: Hes 20 feet tall and weighs 2,000 pounds. Hes monstrous, but, his creators hope, also moving. And hes coming to Broadway this fall.

title: New Sentences: From Chelsea Hodsons Tonight Im Someone Else
description: From Tonight Im Someone Else (Holt Paperbacks, 2018, Page 181), a collection of essays by Chelsea Hodson.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THIS LAND By Dan Barry. (Black Dog & Leventhal, $29.99.) For a decade, from 2007 to 2017, Barrys column for The Times explored everyday life and everyday people in America  from a hairdresser in Vicco, Ky., to the owner of a small oil company in Dixfield, Me. This book collects nearly 100 of his columns, providing a panoramic view of the country as it passed from Bush to Obama to Trump. THE FABULOUS BOUVIER SISTERS By Sam Kashner and Nancy Schoenberger. (Harper, $28.99.) A book-length exploration of the complicated sister love between Jackie Kennedy Onassis and Lee Radziwill (ne Bouvier)  their shared appreciation for fashion and art, as well as the intense jealousy that characterized their relationship. THE ART OF LOGIC IN AN ILLOGICAL WORLD By Eugenia Cheng. (Basic, $27.) Cheng is a mathematician who believes we need to appreciate the value of alogic  emotion, that is  if we want to understand a world filled with irrational behavior. Yet she also thinks smartly applied logic might help address some of our problems. ACCESSORY TO WAR By Neil deGrasse Tyson and Avis Lang. (Norton, $30.) The celebrity astrophysicist and a research associate at the Hayden Planetarium examine the ways military branches have used the science of astrophysics to bolster their power. Its an alliance between science and war-making that has been, Tyson and Lang write, curiously complicit. THE PARTING GIFT By Evan Fallenberg. (Other Press, $19.95.) An erotic, mysterious novel set in Israel that takes the form of a letter. The unnamed narrator describes a consuming love affair that threatens his own well-being and that of the man with whom he has fallen in love.

title: Fall Back Into the School Year With Books by, for and About Teachers
description: Dear Match Book,

title: How to Respond When Someone Comes Out to You
description: Remember that its not about you, says Telaina Eriksen, a creative-writing professor at Michigan State University in East Lansing, who wrote a book about her daughters coming out as a lesbian. No matter what kind of relationship you have with the person, dont immediately turn the conversation to yourself by saying something like I knew it all along! or How could you do this to me? If you are in a position of authority  a parent, teacher or coach  be extra careful; what you say will be imbued with that power differential. Whatever you do, Eriksen says, dont say, Are you sure?

title: True Detective Director Cary Fukunaga Is Bringing His Obsessions to Netflix
description: At the end of 2009, the director Cary Joji Fukunaga was hunting for his second feature film. His first, Sin Nombre, had been an almost preposterously ambitious undertaking for a first-time filmmaker, tracking the intertwining stories of an immigrant and an erstwhile member of MS-13 as they made the dangerous journey to the United States border atop fast-moving train cars, all written by Fukunaga in slang-heavy Spanish. Over the course of two years, he made multiple trips to Mexico, riding the real-life version of these trains and visiting prisons in Chiapas to make connections with gang members who could help ensure that the film had a documentarylike accuracy. I need to believe what Im watching, he says.

title: A Trail of Bread Crumbs, Leading Conspiracy Theorists Into the Wilderness
description: Go hungry for too long, and a lot of strange things will start to look like food. The smallest morsels become precious, especially if you believe they form some kind of trail with a meal at the end. This is true not only of physical sustenance; it is true of knowledge as well. You always find scattered crumbs  inscrutable analogies, esoteric equations, unverified allegations from anonymous sources  gathered around those questions about which we know the least.

title: Americans Want to Believe Jobs Are the Solution to Poverty. Theyre Not.
description: Vanessa Solivan and her three children fled their last place in June 2015, after a young man was shot and killed around the corner. They found a floor to sleep on in Vanessas parents home on North Clinton Avenue in East Trenton. It wasnt a safer neighborhood, but it was a known one. Vanessa took only what she could cram into her station wagon, a 2004 Chrysler Pacifica, letting the bed bugs have the rest.

title: What Should I Do With Old Racist Memorabilia?
description: While renovating our home 30 years ago, we found an album of old postcards lodged in a rafter. Many were from the turn of the century, addressed to members of a family that settled in our community. A brief search at the time did not turn up any descendants.

title: Heres What to Watch in New Hampshires Primary Election
description: Chris Sununu, a Republican and one of the most popular governors in the country, is regarded as an overwhelming favorite to keep his job. But two Democrats are fighting for the privilege of taking him on in the fall.

title: Henry Adamss 1880 Novel, Democracy, Resonates Now More Than Ever
description: She thought she knew what she was about. The heroine of a sensational and successful novel, Democracy, published anonymously in 1880, Madeleine Lee, who is young, rich and beautiful, moves from New York to Washington to pass a season in a house on Lafayette Square.

title: A Top Goldman Banker Raised Ethics Concerns. Then He Was Gone.
description: By the tight-lipped standards of Goldman Sachs, the phone call from one of the firms most senior investment bankers was explosive.

title: A Travel Magazine With a Focus on Feminism
description: Feminism hits the road in the new womens travel magazine, Unearth Women. Launching this month, the quarterly publication was co-founded by its editor in chief, Nikki Vargas, a New York-based travel editor and blogger who said she believes that travel publications largely ignore women, both as contributors and as subjects. Available in print and digital form, the publication combines coverage of womens issues globally, such as Rohingya refugees in Myanmar, and profiles of travel industry mavericks, such as a female tour guide in Iran, with more traditional destination pieces and city guides that highlight women-owned businesses.

title: The 52 Places Traveler: Finding the Real Prague
description: Our columnist, Jada Yuan, is visiting each destination on our 52 Places to Go in 2018 list. This dispatch brings her to Prague; it took the No. 39 spot on the list and is the 34th stop on Jadas itinerary.

title: Primary Season Was Full of Surprises. Heres Why the Polls Missed Some of Them.
description: Ayanna Pressleys blowout victory over a 10-term congressman last week was the latest example of a trend that has become abundantly clear: 2018 is the year of the progressive insurgent, from Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to Andrew Gillum.

title: Sally Field Talks About Her Life In Pieces
description: LOS ANGELES  Even now, just a few days before the release of her memoir, In Pieces, Sally Field wasnt sure she wanted it published. She felt a similar ambivalence throughout the six or so years she spent working on it and wasnt confident, from the moment she composed its first words, that anyone would want to read what she wrote.

title: Inside the Boxes
description: An unconventional addition turned an old house in Portland, Ore., into something even more interesting than an antique.

title: A Portland Craftsman, Cubed
description: Seen from the sidewalk along Lincoln Street, the 1907 Craftsman-style house in Southeast Portland, Ore., looks entirely traditional, with its covered porch, shake siding and exposed roof beams.

title: Stephen Colbert Gives Les Moonves (His Boss) a Shove Out the Door
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. description: These are polarized times. Yet for business leaders across the political spectrum, there is one area of troubling consensus: a contempt for governments ability to regulate effectively.

title: Boring Is the New Black
description: Gail Collins: Bret, weve had such a wild week and soon Ill ask you about all things Trumpian. But first, any thoughts on the Supreme Court? Are you a Brett Kavanaugh fan or foe?

title: If the Regime Comes Here, Everyone Will Be Targeted
description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his Russian allies have escalated aerial bombing of Idlib in northwest Syria, the last rebel-held province in Syria. A major offensive to capture Idlib, where three million people live, is expected.

title: Review: Medieval Monsters? Those Beasts Are Not Extinct
description: One of the first manuscripts you see upon entering the show Medieval Monsters: Terrors, Aliens, Wonders at the Morgan Library & Museum is a 1595 edition of the Flemish cartographer Abraham Orteliuss Theatrum Orbis Terrarum (Theater of the World). The book is open to a map of Iceland featuring rows of mountains, a lava-spewing volcano and an array of monsters, including one that looks like a horse crossed with a mermaid and a prehistoric sea creature. Orteliuss Theatrum is regarded as the first modern atlas, yet, as the exhibition text points out, it still adheres to a medieval view of the world. Fanciful images representing the strangeness and danger of the unknown accompany geographic information.

title: South Korean Leader Urges Bold Decisions on Norths Denuclearization
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As President Trump considers a second summit meeting with Kim Jong-un, President Moon Jae-in of South Korea called Tuesday for both leaders to make bold decisions that will keep the process of North Korean denuclearization moving forward.

title: DealBook Briefing: How the Financial Crisis Helped Elect Trump
description: Good Tuesday. Want this in your inbox every morning? Sign up here.

title: Duterte Dares Military Officers to Rebel Amid Standoff Over Senators Arrest
description: MANILA  President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines on Tuesday challenged military veterans and serving officers who oppose him to mount a rebellion, a day after the head of the armed forces warned soldiers not to take sides in the presidents standoff with a senator he has threatened to arrest.

title: A First for New York: New Conductors at the Met Opera and Philharmonic
description: It wasnt supposed to happen this way, and its never happened this way before: New music directors are arriving this season at both the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera, a coincidence with the potential to transform the citys music scene.

title: First, a Financial Crisis. Then a Geopolitical Crisis.
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

title: California Today: Who Owns the Risk for Earthquakes?
description: Good morning.

title: Proenza Schouler Goes on a Fashion Cleanse
description: This is a moment of returns. Its back-to-school time. Novak Djokovic came back to win the United States Open. Barack Obama has been back on the hustings, providing a clarion call for Democrats. And Proenza Schouler  erstwhile next-gen hope of American fashion, a brand born with the millennium that seemed to effortlessly channel a certain New Yorkiness of the soul, a brand that rode off into the Parisian sunset a year ago  is back on the ready-to-wear schedule.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: $22 MILLION

title: Zimbabwe Declares Cholera Emergency as Disease Spreads in Capital
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  A cholera outbreak in Zimbabwe has killed at least 20 people and sickened 2,000 others in the past week, the countrys new health minister said on Tuesday, as he declared a state of emergency in the capital, Harare.

title: Mark Carney, Bank of England Governor, Will Stay in Charge Until 2020
description: LONDON  Mark J. Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, will stay in his role until the end of January 2020, the government said on Tuesday, which means that he would run the central bank for 10 months after Britains departure from the European Union.

title: The Education of Amandla Stenberg
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  There are roles certain actors seem born to play  an echo of facial symmetry, a rhyming of demeanor  and then there is Starr Carter, the high school junior of The Hate U Give, and Amandla Stenberg, the young actress who seems to embody her almost from sense memory, as if the performance is actually self portraiture.

title: Plunder My Songbook, Bob Dylan Said. So He Did.
description: Bob Dylans fans may cherish his original recordings, but we all love a good cover version, if only as grist for arguments over who does him better. PJ Harvey or Madeleine Peyroux? Bryan Ferry or Cassandra Wilson? Hendrix or Harrison? Nico or Cat Power?

title: A Disappearing Act on Shelter Island
description: Colleen DeCourcys pool house tries to recede, instead of stand out, amid sprawling Hamptons estates.

title: On Shelter Island, a Pool House as Discreet as Its Environs
description: SHELTER ISLAND is tucked inside the northeastern tip of New Yorks Long Island like a barnacle stuck in a lobsters claw, separated by the Peconic River from the Hamptons hamlets that dot the South Fork and the humbler towns of the North Fork. As a destination, the island is distinct from these adjacent enclaves: After being settled by English colonists as part of the 1620 Plymouth land trust, transformed into a 19th-century summer retreat by the citys titans of industry and then abandoned during the Great Depression, it has been rediscovered in the last 50 years by creative types, including the Abstract Expressionist sculptor John Chamberlain, the former Barneys creative director Simon Doonan and his husband, the designer Jonathan Adler, and the actress Julie Kavner (the voice of Marge on The Simpsons).

title: Teaming Up to Get Workers Ready for Technology of the Future
description: Shawn Reese is the perfect example of the complicated route that can lie ahead for workers of the future  but also for the opportunities that are emerging.

title: Is Cash Better for Poor People Than Conventional Foreign Aid?
description: In Matinza, a village in eastern Rwanda, Esther Nyirabazungu, a 63-year-old widow, lives with her son, daughter and two grandchildren in a hut with a dirt floor and no electricity or running water. Her life is hard, but not as hard as it was before she received six monthly cash donations worth about $100 each, with no strings attached, from a United States government trial program.

title: Jon Gruden Fails to Show Why Hes the Raiders $100 Million Man
description: Tough start for Jon Gruden.

title: The Other Biggest Problem in Washington
description: A supine Congress unable to hold a president accountable. Members who find the job miserable (except for the status). A persistent problem of understaffing and lack of policy expertise. For decades, Congress has faced these growing problems and others. The Trump era has thrown them into overdrive.

title: Hunters of Man-Eating Tigress Can Shoot to Kill, Indian Court Rules
description: NEW DELHI  In India, you cant just shoot a tiger.

title: At 9/11 Memorial, Remembering Those Lost
description: The family members and loved ones of the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks gathered under misty skies at the World Trade Center site in Manhattan on Tuesday to honor the legacies of those lost by reading their names aloud in a somber ritual repeated each year on the anniversary of the attacks.

title: New iPhones Are Coming. Heres How to Save on an Upgrade.
description: Its the time of year when smartphone makers introduce their newest wares to tempt you to spend your hard-earned dollars on the latest, priciest devices.

title: Review: Puttin on the Pathos in a Tribute to Irving Berlin
description: Few titles are balder than Hershey Felder as Irving Berlin  or more baldfaced. In the one-man quasi-musical tribute that opened last week at 59E59 Theaters, Mr. Felder plays no version of Berlin the world might recognize or wish to.

title: How Season 2 of Atypical Improves the Shows Depictions of Life as an Autistic Person
description: The first season of the Netflix series Atypical introduced audiences to the Gardners, a suburban Connecticut family with an autistic teenage son, Sam (Keir Gilchrist), at its center. As an autistic viewer, the coming-of-age story inspired familiar frustrations for me with how the disability is usually represented in popular culture: white, cisgender, straight, intellectually gifted and totally lacking in human empathy.

title: Review: Jean-Pierre Melvilles When You Read This Letter Is a Vexing Noir
description: Thrse Voise is a novice in a rural French convent, about to take her final vows when her parents are killed in a car accident. She returns home to Cannes to run the family stationery shop and keep an eye on her younger sister, Denise. Meanwhile, Max, a volatile mechanic whose pastimes are prizefighting and tomcatting, seduces a wealthy married woman who lives in a suite at the Carlton Hotel. When he crosses paths with the Voise sisters, the aftermath includes rape, robbery, a suicide attempt and homicide. The usual noir business, in shadowy black and white under the Mediterranean sun.

title: Bombing in Afghanistan Kills at Least 68 at Peaceful Protest
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  Extremists in eastern Afghanistan bombed a peaceful protest on Tuesday, killing at least 68 people, officials said, the deadliest in a series of attacks in Nangarhar Province over the day.

title: Andrew Zimmerns Nonstop Road (and Food) Show
description: WAYZATA, Minn.  On a warm August evening at an outdoor charity rock concert not far from Minneapolis, restlessness overtook Andrew Zimmern.

title: Nigella Seeds and Rose-Water Sorbet
description: Sofreh, in Brooklyn, celebrates the pleasures of the Iranian table.

title: For Fans of Irans Sophisticated Cuisine, a Reason to Cheer
description: Considering the history, the influence, the depth and the sophistication of Iranian food, it has always seemed unfair that New York City has so few places to eat it. Unfair to the cuisine and unfair to would-be eaters.

title: Anonymous Is Hiding in Plain Sight
description: More and more, I wonder if the disgruntled senior Trump administration official who wrote the anonymous Op-Ed in The Times was actually representing a group  like a Murder on the Orient Express plotline where every senior Trump adviser was in on it. Why? Because the article so perfectly captured the devils bargain theyve all struck with this president: Donald Trump is amoral, dishonest and disturbed, a man totally unfit to be president, but, as the anonymous author self-servingly wrote, There are bright spots that the near-ceaseless negative coverage of the administration fails to capture: effective deregulation, historic tax reform, a more robust military and more.

title: Nathan Lane and Andrea Martin Will Star in New Taylor Mac Play
description: Who cleans up after politicians make a mess? Taylor Mac, the intentionally outrageous performance artist/playwright, has been pondering that question, and will offer an answer on Broadway next spring.

title: Replacing One Bad Bail System With Another
description: Bail reform is hot. From New Jersey to California, and Rand Paul to Bernie Sanders, there is widespread agreement that the cash bail system is broken. It privileges people with money, allowing them to buy their freedom. People who cant afford bail are forced to choose between taking a guilty plea or waiting for trial behind bars.

title: Ethiopia-Eritrea Border Opens for First Time in 20 Years
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  Astebeha Tesfaye went to visit friends in Eritrea, and had to stay 20 years.

title: They Defied Trump on Climate Change. Now, Its Their Moment of Truth.
description: Hours after President Trump announced last year that the United States would exit the Paris climate deal, a broad group of governors, mayors and business executives declared that they would uphold the agreement anyway and continue tackling global warming on their own.

title: A Diagnosis Update: New Information on a Young Girls Rare Genetic Condition
description: Last week I presented the case of the 6-year-old girl in South Dakota who had episodes of transient muscle weakness dozens of times a day, starting around the time she turned 1. The events seemed to be triggered by strong emotions, particularly joy. She had thorough work-ups as neurologists, first in South Dakota, then at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., tried to figure out the cause of these odd spells. Just before she turned 4, Kamiyah was accepted into the National Institutes of Healths Undiagnosed Diseases Network  truly the diagnosticians of last resort. She spent a week in Bethesda, Md., getting test after test, as doctors there searched for disorders that could cause the symptoms she was experiencing. All that testing finally produced an answer: She had a genetic abnormality causing these attacks of muscular weakness.

title: Trump Honors Heroes of Flight 93 on Sept. 11 Anniversary
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump paid tribute on Tuesday to the airline passengers and crew members who stormed the cockpit of a hijacked plane and thwarted terrorists in the skies over Pennsylvania on Sept. 11, 2001, vowing to follow their example by standing up to evil in the world.

title: I Found My Girlfriends Sex Tape Online. Should I Tell Her?
description: Dear Sugars,

title: Your Questions About FIRE, Answered
description: How to Retire in Your 30s with $1 Million in the Bank, a Times article about the FIRE movement (it stands for financial independence, retire early), generated a lot of reader responses.

title: Teaching and Doing Can Go Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Evacuating for a Hurricane: How to Prepare Yourself
description: When a hurricane is poised to make landfall and the authorities issue an evacuation order, you may not have much time before you leave to protect your home from the storm  and from flooding.

title: A Fine-Dining Veteran Turns to Street Food
description: Diana Tandias path has taken her from her native Mauritania to Paris and finally to New York, where she studied political science at Borough of Manhattan Community College. The next step was the French Culinary Institute (now the International Culinary Center), and then the kitchens of Daniel Boulud and Jean-Georges Vongerichten. Now, nearly 40, she has opened her own place, Berber Street Food, a minuscule canteen where she draws on her high-end experience to serve well-prepared street food specialties from Morocco, Nigeria, Senegal, the Sahara and other parts of Africa, even touching down in the Caribbean with accra fritters and jerk wings. Senegalese djolof fried rice, Nigerian brochettes and a Moroccan vegetable tagine are a few of the other dishes on the menu. The restaurant, brightened with African fabrics, baskets and rainbow piles of hot chiles, seats 15 at chairs and stools, and fields a steady stream of customers for takeout. Going out on my own, I did not want to stay in fine dining, she said. Still, her presentation is gracious, overcoming the constraints of paper napkins and plastic utensils.

title: Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers and Lucy Dacus Formed an Indie-Rock Supergroup
description: For a young musician to crash, suddenly, into renown and adoration can be disorienting. Writing and performing songs may turn fraught with expectations. The road becomes home; communing with audiences of strangers stands in for human connection. Its a dream  and also just plain weird.

title: On the Debt Non-Spiral
description: The debate between Joe Stiglitz and Larry Summers over secular stagnation is a somewhat embarrassing affair, which I hope will soon be forgotten. Joe, one of our greatest living economists, seems to have misunderstood what secular stagnation means  which is, to be fair, easy given how unintuitive the term is. And he accused Larry of inventing the doctrine to justify the Obama administrations policy shortfalls.

title: Celebrating the Fish Fry, a Late-Summer Black Tradition
description: The chef Todd Richards remembers the fish fries that his mother hosted for their family in Chicago: The gatherings would spill into the street from their front yard.

title: How to Cook in Your Dorm Room, First Apartment and Beyond
description: Welcome to The Edit newsletter. Each week youll hear from college students and recent graduates about issues going on in their lives. You also may hear from me, Lindsey Underwood, editor of the newsletter. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

title: Playing Games Can Be Hard Work. So Can Choosing Which Ones to Display.
description: LONDON  Last week, Marie Foulston stood in the Victoria and Albert Museum trying to explain what was so groundbreaking about a host of recent video games. At the same time, she was trying to play one, controlling a horse onscreen that was, absurdly, driving a taxi cab.

title: Does the Cost of Living in New York Spell the End of Its Artistic Life?
description: WHEN THE GALLERIST Ellie Rines wants to show work in storage to collectors, all she has to do is head up to her bed. The proprietor and resident of the small Lower Manhattan storefront gallery 56 Henry, Rines recently staged an exhibition of pillow-esque soft sculptures by the artist Al Freeman, and when the exhibition ended, some of the work naturally made its way from the walls to her sleeping loft in the back of her business, which she refers to as the gallerys mezzanine level. The loft is not without peril. You start to fall down really slowly, then it happens really fast, she says, recounting one of her tumbles. Its like a coffin back here.

title: A Toast to the Bride and Groom (With Their Signature Cocktails)
description: When Richard Swan and Josh Rosenthal, founders of the creative beverage service the Grand Bevy, first saw Snoop Dogg post an image on Instagram of his face on a cocktail, they knew they had created something great.

title: At MoMA, How Judson Blew Up the Rules of Dance
description: A group of dancers sat on the floor of a gallery at the Museum of Modern Art one day last week, looking intently at two plywood boxes. The room was motionless and silent except for what sounded a little like bird song. Walking in mid-rehearsal, you might not have realized there were people inside the boxes, whistling  heard but not seen.

title: It Was a Symbol of Lost New York: Readers Remember Their Favorite New York City Spots
description: The one thing about New York that never changes is that its always changing. Its a longstanding New York pastime to lament this phenomenon to which it seems like all of our most beloved haunts fall victim.

title: New Hampshire Primary Election Results
description: See full results and maps from the New Hampshire primaries.

title: Yet Another Way to Eat Your Spinach
description: Tunisian Jews make a condiment called pkaila or bkeila, which is extraordinary. It is prepared by cooking down plenty of spinach for hours in a generous quantity of oil. The spinach  Swiss chard is often used as well  loses all its water, and very slowly fries in the oil, resulting in a small amount of greasy paste as black as crude oil, which is used to flavor all kinds of soups and stews.

title: For the First Time, Thelonious Monks Songbook Swings Solo
description: I think if Monk was alive, hed be really, really annoyed with me, the pianist Jed Distler said recently. He knew exactly how he wanted his music to sound.

title: Thoughts on Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dress in His Painting? She Designed It
description: The artist Ben Sledsens and the fashion designer Charlotte De Geyter met three years ago, while both were students at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp. In the time since, the couple has become virtually inseparable  and their work, which shares points of inspiration and a bright sensibility, has become increasingly intertwined. De Geyter has carved out a small atelier in their airy shared apartment in Antwerps Harmonie neighborhood. Just a few buildings down is the studio where Sledsens paints.

title: To Fix the Subway, Vote in State Elections
description: This is part of a series on what is at stake in New Yorks primary elections on Thursday, and in the general election on Nov. 6.

title: Smearing Cynthia Nixon
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Blame Google, Mr. Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: Worker at Arizona Center for Migrant Children Is Convicted of Sexual Abuse
description: A youth care worker at an Arizona shelter for migrant children has been convicted of sexually abusing teenagers who were under his supervision, federal prosecutors said on Monday.

title: Oscar de la Renta: Spring 2019
description: Oscar de la Renta Spring 2019 Collection

title: E.U.s Leadership Seeks to Contain Hungarys Orban
description: BRUSSELS  As Prime Minister Viktor Orban steadily established an illiberal state in Hungary, dismantling the countrys checks and balances, stacking its constitutional court with loyalists and creating a template for other far-right leaders, a powerful group of European politicians took note.

title: Midterm Election Poll: Wisconsins 1st District, Steil vs. Bryce
description: This district is a mix of farmland, industrial towns and the suburbs of Milwaukee.

title: Gabriela Hearst: Spring 2019
description: Gabriela Hearst Spring 2019 Collection

title: A Trump Visit to Ireland Is Now Up in the Air
description: DUBLIN  Irish officials were surprised two weeks ago to learn that President Trump planned to stop by their country in November when he visited France.

title: 7 Roles. 14 Actors. 2 Languages. 1 Stage.
Whats Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 12, 2018
description: Updated: September 13, 2018

title: Tax Breaks for Luxury Towers Spur Redevelopment, and Backlash
description: Twenty years ago, it was unimaginable that a new residential high-rise would ever adorn the modest skyline of downtown Kansas City, Mo. But in the last three years, two luxury apartment towers have opened, and a third is planned.

title: Prosecutors Are Said to Issue Subpoenas Over Pelvic-Mesh Surgery Financing
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn are intensifying an investigation into allegations that a network of doctors, lawyers, financiers and consultants lured women into having pelvic mesh implants removed, according to the two people familiar with the matter.

title: After Migrants Drowned at Sea, Debate Over Who Should Have Saved Them
description: ROME  Dozens of migrants  possibly more than 100 people  drowned in the Mediterranean Sea while trying to reach Europe this month after their boat sank and passengers waited in the water for hours until a rescue ship arrived, according to Doctors Without Borders.

title: Was There a Double Standard for Judging Serena Williams?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lake Bell, Carmelo Anthony and Liev Schreiber Party at Fashion Week
description: Celebrations were held Monday night for Rag & Bone and Garage Magazine.

title: Beyond Crazy Rich Asians: Angie Wang Makes a Movie
description: Crystal meth? As if.

title: A Cartoonists Flock of Pigeons Fit for Fashion Week
description: One of the greatest pleasures of fashion month might be the people-watching opportunities that come with it. For close to four full weeks, flocks of editors and influencers can be counted on to buzz about in their most prized  and often beautifully impractical  possessions. In this feature, we pay tribute to one of the overlooked populations of the worlds fashion capitals: pigeons. Here, we imagine what they would look like if they took a break from their gray, no-nonsense pigeon wear and tried on some of the new human styles of fall 2018. The answer: Not bad.

title: The Red Ball That Bounced Through Toledo (in 2015) Is on the Move Again
description: If art is meant to bring joy, this work certainly did: a giant red 250-pound ball that broke free of its handlers, bounced down a street in Toledo, Ohio, over a couple of cars and into internet fame for a hot minute in 2015.

title: The Slippery Slope of Regulating Social Media
description: The promise of the internet, and social media in particular, was that it would not only allow anyone the opportunity to speak, but would also make it possible for anyone to precisely tailor what he reads, sees and hears online. News and information would no longer be mediated by newspaper editors, television producers and other gatekeepers. Instead, social media would allow direct access to individual voices in a feed custom-built by the user. It was a new frontier for both unregulated free expression and individual control.

title: As the News Cycle Lurches, Jill Lepore Offers a Long, Steady View of American History
description: We know how all of this is going to end: with Donald J. Trump.

title: Review: Drugs, Guns and Poses in White Boy Rick
description: A fiction built on nonfiction, White Boy Rick traces the grim, grubby rise and predictable fall of Richard Wershe Jr. (the newcomer Richie Merritt), a Detroit drug dealer who was arrested in 1987 at 17. Rick Jr. earns his catchy nickname soon after he starts running with powerful black street gangsters who inexplicably welcome him into their fold, as if he were one of them. (The White Boy name might have been a media fantasy about the characters putative exoticism, at least thats what the real Mr. Wershe suggested to The Guardian in 2015. They did it to glorify or glamorize, he said, as if he were an anomaly.)

title: Review: In Lizzie, an Oppressed Daughter Driven to Murder
description: There is something wildly freeing about the savage killings in Lizzie, a distinctly feminist take on the notorious Lizzie Borden, historys most famous, if unproven, mom-and-pop slayer. This sense of liberation derives from murders enacted with the methodical exhilaration of a jailbreak  a cathartic response to years of oppression by her miserly father, Andrew (Jamey Sheridan), and loathed stepmother, Abby (Fiona Shaw). And when Lizzie strips naked before hacking her two tormentors to slivers, her nudity isnt simply practical: Its the repudiation of a 19th-century wardrobe that controlled womens movements as thoroughly as men did.

title: Are We Being Misled About Precision Medicine?
description: Facing incurable breast cancer at age 55, MaryAnne DiCanto put her faith in precision medicine  in which doctors try to match patients with drugs that target the genetic mutations in their tumors. She underwent repeated biopsies to identify therapies that might help.

title: Is Donald Trump a Fascist?
description: HOW FASCISM WORKS The Politics of Us and Them By Jason Stanley 218 pp. Random House. $26.

title: In an Increasingly Diverse House, Aides Remain Remarkably White
description: WASHINGTON  House aides write federal policy and multitrillion-dollar budgets, oversee the administration of government and shape the publics view of Congress, but the top staff members of the House of Representatives are far less racially diverse than the country itself  or even the lawmakers who employ them.

title: A Hotel Where Every Room Is a Work of Art
description: The artist Jorge Pardo makes work that not only lives outside the confines of the traditional white cube but also interrogates notions of space and setting and our place within them. One of his best-known pieces dates to 1998, when, for a show with the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, he designed a single-story house in the citys Cypress Park neighborhood and filled it with objects of his own making. Once the exhibition closed, Pardo moved in. Im essentially appropriating architecture, says Pardo, who now lives in Mrida, Mexico, in another structure that could be considered both art piece and functional living space  a birdcage in the jungle complete with a hand-painted mural and ovoid pendant lights.

title: Can Germanys Center Hold Against the Far Right?
description: BERLIN  Only a week after several right-wing marches took place in the eastern German town of Chemnitz, protesters took to the streets on Sunday night in Kthen, a city of about 26,000 people located 90 miles southwest of Berlin. Again, video footage showed ugly scenes, including one group shouting, National Socialism, now, now, now.

title: The Best Photos From New York Fashion Week, Day 5
description: It was still dreary outside on the fifth day of New York Fashion Week, but the energy was high inside the venues, where our photographers saw designers and models prepping to show collections.

title: Beauty or Beast? Iceland Quarrels Over an Invasive Plant
description: FSKRDSFJRDUR, Iceland  In the cool morning air, an assortment of Icelandic warriors headed for their battlefield  armed with long knives and weed whackers.

title: Viola Davis on What The Help Got Wrong and How She Proves Herself
description: TORONTO  The Oscar-winning actress Viola Davis is the star of the new crime drama Widows, which debuted here last week at the Toronto International Film Festival and will be in theaters Nov. 16.

title: Jeff Lowe, Pathfinder Up the Face of Mountains, Is Dead at 67
description: It was February 1991, and for nine days Jeff Lowe had been climbing alone up the punishing, nearly 6,000-foot north face of the Eiger, a notoriously dangerous mountain in the Swiss Alps that had claimed the lives of more than 50 climbers over the years.

title: As Elkhart, Ind., Goes, So Goes the Nation, and Elkhart Is Nervous
description: ELKHART, Ind.  The tables were filled at the Chubby Trout restaurant and the local craft beer flowed. The Flippin Cow was packed too, with diners overlooking Simonton Lake. Small manufacturing companies were advertising for workers, offering health insurance and retirement accounts.

title: David Wright Is Getting Better. But Will the Mets Allow His Return?
description: Only three weeks left in season they would rather forget, a large group of Mets players, coaches, executives and staff members gathered Saturday afternoon behind the batting cage at Citi Field to watch and wonder about the man who has meant so much to the franchise.

title: Coach 1941: Spring 2019
description: Coach 1941 Spring 2019 Collection

title: Listen Up: Here Are 3 Books on the Sexism Women Face in Hollywood.
description: Leslie Moonves is the latest Hollywood executive to step down after several women came forward with accusations of sexual misconduct. These three books, at times sober and hilarious, tell the experiences of women in television, while one assesses how far theyve come.

title: Sleep Apnea May Increase Risk of Gout
description: New research has found that obstructive sleep apnea  a disorder in which breathing stops and starts during sleep  is associated with an increased risk for gout, a common cause of painful arthritis.

title: Your Wednesday News Briefing: The Philippines, India, Cartoon
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Are You Preparing for Hurricane Florence? We Want to Hear From You
description: Evacuations are underway in coastal areas of North Carolina, South Carolina and Virginia, with more than a million residents preparing to leave ahead of Hurricane Florence.

title: Kulsoom Nawaz, Wife of Jailed Former Pakistan Leader, Is Dead
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Kulsoom Nawaz, wife of the jailed former Pakistani leader Nawaz Sharif, died on Tuesday after a protracted battle with cancer in London, family members said.

title: 48 Hours With Rodarte
description: Ahead of their first New York show in two years, the designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy invited T into their studio.

title: The Rodarte Sisters Dramatic Return to New York
description: It was an oppressively sultry Wednesday afternoon, and New York City felt like a sauna. Weve had extremely hot days on the West Coast this summer, too, but I forgot how different it is here with the humidity, said Laura Mulleavy, one half of the fashion label Rodarte. Earlier that week, she and her business partner and sister, Kate, had flown in from Los Angeles, where their label is based, to begin preparations for their first New York runway show in two years.

title: Tips for Travelers Affected by Hurricane Florence
description: While the Southeast braces for the first major hurricane of the year later this week, other storms are brewing in the Caribbean and the Pacific. Hurricane season runs June 1 to Nov. 30 annually, but generally peaks in mid-August to late October, according to the National Hurricane Center.  Expect travel disruptions in the Mid-Atlantic, Caribbean and Hawaii because of the following four storms. Below are tips for navigating travel during the storms and their aftermaths.

title: On Politics With Lisa Lerer: Cynthia Nixon Talks Bagels, Polls and Cuomo
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host. Its Primary Day in New Hampshire.

title: KiKi Layne, Beale Streets Breakout Star, Has a 4 a.m. Moment
description: The night before If Beale Street Could Talk had its premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival, the movies leading lady, KiKi Layne, found herself sleepless in couture. She had just left a party where everyone knew her director, Barry Jenkins, whose last film was the best-picture winner Moonlight. But the 26-year-old Ms. Layne, who makes her film debut in Beale Street, was still a mystery to people. And the next day, she would no longer be.

title: Beauty Is More Diverse Than Ever. But Is It Diverse Enough?
description: In an era of makeup collections with 40 foundation colors and more spokesmodels of color than ever before, diversity at the beauty counter would seem to be accepted, even celebrated.

title: Vaquera: Spring 2019
description: Vaquera Spring 2019 Collection.

title: These 3 Hurricane Misconceptions Can Be Dangerous. Scientists Want to Clear Them Up.
description: They warn. They plead. They scold and cajole. Forecasters and public officials will try just about anything to get residents to flee coastlines ahead of a hurricane. Last year as Hurricane Harvey barreled toward the Gulf Coast, the mayor pro tem of Rockport, Tex., said people who insisted on staying should mark their arm with a Sharpie pen  put their Social Security number on it and their name.

title: Your Tuesday Evening News Briefing: 9/11, Hurricane Florence, Serena Williams
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: How 3 Little Letters (I.D.C.) Are Riling Up New York Progressives
description: If you have paid even a little attention to New York politics recently, there is a good chance you have heard the letters I.D.C. If you have paid a little more attention, you may have heard the group blamed for a host of issues: New Yorks failure to codify Roe v. Wade into law; its flimsy protections for child sex-abuse victims; its lack of more stringent gun control laws.

title: Is It a Category 2, 3 or 5? How Florence and Other Hurricanes Are Classified
description: As Florence approached the East Coast last week, meteorologists downgraded the storm, which made landfall in North Carolina as a Category 1 hurricane.

title: The Daily Transcript: Interview With Bob Woodward
description: In his new book, Fear: Trump in the White House, Bob Woodward deploys the form of reporting that he pioneered when he covered the Nixon administration to tell the story of the Trump White House. He spoke about his process with Michael S. Schmidt, a Washington correspondent for The New York Times, on an episode of The Daily. You can find out more about the episode here.

title: Is Whole-Fat Dairy Good for the Heart?
description: A large new study links whole-fat dairy food consumption to a reduced risk for cardiovascular disease. The findings raise questions about current dietary guidelines, which suggest substituting fat-free or low-fat dairy for full-fat products.

title: Writing About Fried Fish, With a Side of History
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

title: He Led a Group of Disloyal New York Democrats. Will It Cost Him His Seat?
description: Money and power are no strangers to Senator Jeffrey D. Klein, so it should be no surprise that with his political life on the line, he is aggressively deploying both.

title: How to Mentor a Teen to Use Tech Responsibly
description: Children at this age want more freedom and privacy, but you still need to make sure theyre safe online. Here are some tips for staying connected while maintaining their trust.

title: Seeking Human Generositys Origins in an Apes Gift to Another Ape
description: How generous is an ape? Its a hard question for scientists to tackle, but the answer could tell us a lot about ourselves.

title: A Horrific Crime on the Subway Led to Kendras Law. Years Later, Has It Helped?
description: Nearly two decades ago, in a Manhattan subway station, a mentally ill man shoved Kendra Webdale, a promising young writer, to her death in front of an oncoming N train.

title: Cuomo Campaign Shifts Blame for Inflammatory Flier About Cynthia Nixon to Constituency Representative
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the New York State Democratic Party both acknowledge the existence of a false piece of campaign material that wrongly implied that his primary opponent, Cynthia Nixon, was anti-Semitic. They say it went to 7,000 households, and cost about $11,000. And they both say it was wrong.

title: Hundreds of Thousands of Catalans Rally for Independence in Barcelona
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Hundreds of thousands of pro-independence Catalans took over downtown Barcelona on Tuesday, in their largest show of force since a botched declaration of independence from Spain last October.

title: The Most Contrarian College in America
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Have I got a college for you. For your first two years, your regimen includes ancient Greek. And I do mean Greek, the language, not Greece, the civilization, though youll also hang with Aristotle, Aeschylus, Thucydides and the rest of the gang. Theres no choice in the matter. Theres little choice, period.

title: Corporate Sponsors for NASA? Agency to Study Making Space for Brands
description: Jim Bridenstine, NASAs administrator, posed a question two weeks ago.

title: Henry Bawnik, Survivor of Death Camps and an Inferno at Sea, Dies at 92
description: Henry Bawnik was 15 when his concentration camp odyssey began. Rounded up with others in the Jewish ghetto of Lodz, Poland, during the summer of 1941, he survived hunger, desperation and beatings as he moved from Gutenbrunn to Auschwitz and from Furstengrube to Dora-Mittelbau.

title: Stay Out of Venezuela, Mr. Trump
description: America shouldnt be in the coup business. Period.

title: More Than 1,100 School Faucets Still Have Lead, City Says
description: Lead contamination has been an ongoing crisis in New York Citys public housing, and the Education Department said on Tuesday that it continues to be an issue in schools as well.

title: Cosbys Lawyers and Wife Seek Judges Recusal Before Sentencing
description: PHILADELPHIA  Just two weeks before Bill Cosbys sentencing, his wife and his defense team on Tuesday asked Judge Steven T. ONeill, who has presided over the sexual assault case, to recuse himself, arguing that he had failed to disclose a bitter feud with a key witness in the case.

title: Trump's Huge Mistake on Refugees
description: When President Bashar al-Assads forces swept into the southwestern Syrian region of Daraa this summer, American diplomats scrambled to save the lives of a few hundred besieged civil defense workers known as the White Helmets.

title: Quotation of the Day: 17 Years After 9/11, We Cant Forget
description: Life wont let us forget.

title: Interest Groups Turn Up Pressure on Senators Before Kavanaugh Vote
description: WASHINGTON  Pressure is intensifying on undecided senators before a vote to confirm President Trumps Supreme Court nominee, with one senator  Susan Collins, Republican of Maine  reporting that she and her staff have been targeted with a barrage of calls, including some using vulgar language and threats to push her to vote against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh.

title: The Cardinals Morph Into the Cardinals
description: WASHINGTON  The poor bat girl. Mike Shildt still remembers her. He always empathized with the staffers who make the game go  the clubhouse attendants and the scoreboard operators and the kids chasing foul balls to save the owner a few bucks. He had filled all those roles as a boy.

title: We Dont Need This: The Carolinas Brace for Hurricane Florence
description: For the latest updates, read Wednesdays Hurricane Florence live briefing here.

title: Trump Calls Storm Response in Puerto Rico, Where 3,000 Died, One of the Best
description: President Trump patted himself on the back Tuesday for an incredibly successful job done in Puerto Rico, where the government estimates that  nearly 3,000 people died as a result of Hurricane Maria last year.

title: As Florences Power Nears the Carolinas, Residents Brace for the Worst
description: [For the latest updates on Hurricane Florence, read Wednesdays live briefing here.]

title: In Texas, Ted Cruz Has a Dogfight on His Hands, Some Republicans Admit
description: HOUSTON  Days after a top adviser to President Trump questioned Senator Ted Cruzs chances of winning re-election, the Texas lawmaker casually stepped into the pinnacle of his hometowns energy industry on Tuesday  the lobby of the Petroleum Club of Houston, on the 35th floor of a downtown skyscraper.

title: Donald Trump Jr. Complains His Father Is Served by Few He Can Trust
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump, a commander in chief with a well-known bunker mentality, has long doubted the ability of his aides to protect him from outside attacks. But his anxiety about whom he can trust has only increased in the days since anonymous administration members  a number of them in Bob Woodwards book Fear, and one in an opinion piece published in The New York Times  laid out in stark detail concerns about his volatile personality and doubts about his ability to lead.

title: Molly Kelly Wins in New Hampshire and Will Face Sununu for Governors Seat
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Democratic voters in New Hampshire selected Molly Kelly, a former state senator, as their nominee for governor on Tuesday, as female candidates for governorships continue to show their strength in primary elections this year.

title: Education Dept. Reopens Rutgers Case Charging Discrimination Against Jewish Students
description: The new head of civil rights at the Education Department has reopened a seven-year-old case brought by a Zionist group against Rutgers University, saying the Obama administration, in closing the case, ignored evidence that suggested the school allowed a hostile environment for Jewish students.

title: Corrections: September 12, 2018
description: TIMES INSIDER

title: Cardinal Wuerl, Archbishop of Washington, Plans to Discuss Resignation With Pope
description: Facing an uproar over revelations that he mismanaged past cases of clerical sexual abuse, Cardinal Donald Wuerl, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Washington, sent a letter informing his priests on Tuesday that he plans to discuss his resignation with Pope Francis in Rome.

title: Review: Reversing Roe Shows How Abortion Became Political
description: For those who found the discussion of abortion at last weeks Supreme Court hearings abstract or technical, the documentary Reversing Roe, from Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg, provides a clear and accessible overview of more than 50 years of the social and legal history of the issue in the United States.

title: Julia Childs PBS Show
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Jeffrey Wechsler provides a bit of sustenance to get us through the middle of the week and, if thats not enough, he also acquaints us with the literal translations of some familiar French food terms. They are not always what they seem.

title: The Big Hole in Germanys Nazi Reckoning? Its Colonial History
description: BERLIN  It is, at a glance, an unremarkable street  roughly a quarter-mile long, cutting through a grassy knoll the size of a couple of basketball courts.

title: U.S. Is Said to Allow Sanctions on Foreigners Accused of Interfering in Elections
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration is preparing a new executive order to allow sanctions of foreign citizens suspected of interference in the American elections, officials who have reviewed the order said.

title: Calvin Klein: Spring 2019

title: Edgy Investors Are Retreating From Risky Economies
description: Cratering currencies, rising inflation, jumpy investors: A financial panic is again gripping some of the worlds developing economies.

title: Sonny Gray Wilts in a Spot Start for the Yankees
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The Yankees did not acquire Sonny Gray last year at the trade deadline to be an occasional fill-in. An All-Star with the Oakland Athletics in 2015, Gray was expected to be a stalwart of the rotation, not a surplus arm for whom Manager Aaron Boone had to find a spot.

title: Financial Saga The Lehman Trilogy Is Headed to New York
description: A play about the Lehman brothers will arrive next year in New York, the city where the financial firm bearing their name collapsed in 2008.

title: Its Not Just You: 2017 Was Rough for Humanity, Study Finds
description: Violence, bitter partisanship, an uncertain future. These are dark times.

title: Jacob deGrom Breaks Century-Old Record in Mets Loss
description: Jacob deGrom continued to go unrewarded during a record-breaking season, taking the loss despite allowing just two runs over seven innings on Tuesday night as the Mets fell to the Miami Marlins, 5-3, in the opener of a four-game series at Citi Field.

title: On Politics: A Contentious Take on Anti-Semitism
description: Good Wednesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

title: Brexit and the Land of the Porridge People
description: There are few better ways to irritate the British than to suggest that our food is revolting. These days, we like to think of ourselves as an island of gourmets. If anyone implies otherwise, we become dyspeptic.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday: American Horror Story and Dopesick Nation
description: American Horror Story returns to FX. And Vicelands Dopesick Nation documents the opioid crisis.

title: Serena Williams Cartoon, Called Racist, Gets New Life on Papers Front Page
description: SYDNEY, Australia  An Australian newspaper has defended its decision to publish a provocative cartoon of the tennis star Serena Williams, using the image again  this time on its front page  and railing against politically correct critics who deemed the drawing racist.

title: Norm Macdonald Compounds Problems With Down Syndrome Comment
description: NBC canceled Norm Macdonalds appearance on The Tonight Show Tuesday after he made comments defending several entertainers accused of wrongdoing, including Louis C. K. and Roseanne Barr.

title: Word + Quiz: panache
Gymnastics on Horseback
description: A recent Times piece reports on a sport called vaulting in which athletes in sparkling leotards perform gymnastics to music on the back of a horse thats cantering in a 15-meter circle.

title: South Korean Golfers Create New Rivalry on L.P.G.A. Tour
description: Just as the golfer Se Ri Pak battled the perennial L.P.G.A. contenders Annika Sorenstam and Karrie Webb for tournament wins in the late 1990s and early 2000s, there is a new budding rivalry.

title: On the L.P.G.A. Tour, Its Anyones Game
description: When Cristie Kerr first earned her way onto the L.P.G.A. tour as a teenager, Annika Sorenstam was just setting out on her dominant run.

title: Six Women to Watch at the Evian
description: The Evian Championship will bring the L.P.G.A. to the Evian Resort Golf Club in Evian-les-Bains, France, this week for the final major of 2018.

title: Learning With: China Is Detaining Muslims in Vast Numbers. The Goal: Transformation.
description: Before reading the article:

title: Highlighting Freedom, Resilience and Diversity at Photoville in Brooklyn
description: Every September, thousands of visitors breathe life into a waterfront strip under the Brooklyn Bridge at Photoville, where shipping containers become galleries featuring a dizzying range of photographs. Themes of gender, social and ethnic diversity, resilience, freedom of speech, and immigration make this a perfect event for New York City and  presented by the Annenberg Space for Photography as of next spring  Los Angeles, both cities marked by thriving cultures built by people from different backgrounds.

title: Gender Is a Construct. Christine and the Queens Built a Bulldozer.
description: In the spring of 2017, the French pop singer, songwriter, producer and choreographer Hlise Letissier felt ready to reintroduce herself.

title: The Meaning of the Moon, From the Incas to the Space Race
description: COPENHAGEN  Outside Denmarks Louisiana Museum of Modern Art on a recent late-summer morning, a few sunstruck visitors were sprawling on the turf of the sculpture garden, between monumental outdoor works by Alexander Calder and Richard Serra. Beyond them, facing east toward Sweden, the waters of the Oresund strait were a serene blue, lightly scalloped with wind. The scent of freshly cut grass was in the air.

title: Jimmy Fallon Expects to See More White House Tell-All Books
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If youre interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

title: Google Knows Where Youve Been, but Does It Know Who You Are?
description: In August, The Associated Press published an investigation into how Google handles the data it collects, following a curious discovery by a graduate researcher at U.C. Berkeley. For years, the company has allowed users to control their location history, which stores a detailed record of where theyve been, based primarily on their activity in Google Maps. This, the researcher suggested  and The A.P. confirmed  did not work as advertised. Some Google apps automatically store time-stamped location data without asking, the reporters found. The revelation has since resulted in at least one lawsuit, as well as renewed public criticism from lawmakers.

title: John Kerry Says the World Is Worried About America
description: A memoir like your new book, Every Day Is Extra, often means people are shaping their legacy. Is that something youre thinking about now? No, I dont look at the book as a political book. I really view it as a personal exploration of my life. The things I write about are the things most people have heard about. Its an opportunity for me to set the record straight in a number of cases.

title: Traveling in Vietnam, His Leg Swelled Terribly. Had He Caught Something?
description: It was almost dawn when the 19-year-old was awakened by terrible leg pain. He had no idea how long he was asleep, but it had been a horrible night so far. He and his father arrived in Hanoi the day before. Theyd spent the day seeing the sights, and the evening eating  then drinking. Hed come back to the hotel jet-lagged and hot and a little drunk. He made it to his bed and fell asleep fully clothed. A few hours later, he was woken by cramps in his stomach. Over the next couple of hours, everything hed taken in that evening came out. It was awful. Only when there was nothing left could he go back to bed.

title: Finding Gear for Teens to Try Out Hobbies
description: Get a group of parents of tweens and teens together and soon enough the conversation turns to how busy they all are shuttling multiple kids among multiple activities, clubs and sports. There are advantages to being part of a team, a theater group or a volunteer organization, and many young people thrive on the connections they develop there.

title: The Epicenter of the Housing Bust Is Booming Again. (Thats a Warning Sign.)
description: Prices are soaring in North Las Vegas, which helped spark the global financial crisis a decade ago. But many in the middle class are still struggling to regain what was lost.

title: The Banks Changed. Except for All the Ways Theyre the Same.
description: They are taking less risk and holding more capital. But the powerful industry is also making record profits and is still dominated by huge firms.

title: The Next Financial Calamity Is Coming. Heres What to Watch.
description: Fast-growing pockets of debt could be a source of trouble.

title: In a Hurry? Try Express Weight Training
description: Heres some good news for anyone who does not have the time or inclination to linger in the gym and grunt through repeated, hourslong sets of various weight-training exercises in order to build muscular strength.

title: Spoil Them a Little With Homemade French Fries
description: Here you stand at the sink, washing your plate  the light slants harder than yesterday, you realize; back-to-school weather. Caruthers! The end of summer already, and you only just today managed to eat your first B.L.T. In a fit of tardy hustle, you dry your hands and order three dozen Ball jars online. Pull up in Dropbox your pickling recipe for green beans and your basil digestivo recipe, and print two copies, which spill onto the floor in the den. Upstairs, you hear the boys pounding on their mouse pads, still unshowered at 3 oclock in the afternoon, and you yell up to them to get dressed. Time to move it or lose it, you think. New shoes, new backpacks and the major haul from the modest garden  tomatoes, chard, zucchini and beans. Time to start preserving in earnest to hold you over during the long months ahead. You scroll through your contacts to invite a lively, kindred group for the great day of epic canning, promising bottomless cold ros and tomatoes on toast with mayo. Many hands make light work!

title: Does Your Teachers Identity Affect Your Learning?
description: Who has been your favorite teacher ever? Why?

title: What to Do if Your Flight Is Delayed or Canceled
description: As menacing clouds hung heavy over Lower Manhattan, I cruised toward the Holland Tunnel on my way to Newark Liberty International Airport. I refreshed the flight status for my United Airlines flight, and the airlines app showed an on-time departure. Two minutes later, I refreshed it. A red bar suddenly appeared on my smartphone  the flight had gone from on time to canceled. A United rep confirmed by phone that my flight was, indeed, canceled, and I was rebooked on a 6 a.m. flight the following day. I apologized to my Lyft driver, who turned around and took me back to the hotel Id left just 20 minutes earlier.

title: Why Trumps Name Could Be Hurting His N.Y.C. Golf Course and Other City Concessions
description: When Central Park Tours leads groups to the ice skating rink on the south side of Central Park, they reach a point where big red letters spell out the name of the facilitys operator: Trump.

title: The Recovery Threw the Middle-Class Dream Under a Benz
description: Once a year or so, the economist Diane Swonk ventures into the basement of her 1891 Victorian house outside Chicago and opens a plastic box containing the items that mean the most to her: awards, wedding pictures, the clothes she was wearing at the World Trade Center on the day it was attacked. But what she seeks out again and again is a bound diary of the events of the financial crisis and their aftermath.

title: Rhode Island Has a Primary Election Today. Heres What to Know About It.
description: Rhode Islands primary on Wednesday is the second to last ahead of Novembers midterm elections. (New York, on Thursday, has the honor of going last.)

title: The Policymakers Saved the Financial System. And America Never Forgave Them.
description: Its hard to overstate how deeply Americans despised their governments response to the global financial crisis. It has helped shape the last decade of American politics, fueling distrust of powerful institutions and speeding a drift toward ideological extremes.

title: The Great Recession Knocked Them Down. Only Some Got Up Again.
description: Recession stories tend to begin the same way: lost job, lost home, lost savings. How they end varies much more widely.

title: If This Book Is Not Expressing Everything, What Am I Doing With My Life?
description: Late this spring, off a nondescript hallway in the Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences building at Stanford University, inside a small, windowless office  standing desk; sitting desk; bookcase; chair  the 42-year-old physician Daniel Mason revealed some unease about what we were doing. I come from a tradition, Mason said, in his swift, reassuring cadence, in which some people go into the room without a ring on. So this kind of disclosure is deeply foreign to the kind of work that I do.

title: Three Blockbuster Novels From the 1950s, and Their Remarkable Afterlife
description: Why are Russians so good at vexing American minds? Vladimir Putins bewitchment of President Trump continues to frustrate intelligence officials and at times hard-liners in his own administration, while pro- and anti-Russia journalists trade insults as enthusiastically as they did during the 1950s Rosenberg spy trial.

title: The Housing Bubble Burst All Over Reality TV
description: Before the 2008 crash, home television shows were all about granite countertops and easy cash. Now, after years of hosts promoting home stewardship, is the bling back?

title: The Metamorphosis of Silicon Valley C.E.O.s: From Big to Boring
description: When Joe Barton, a Republican congressman from Texas, greeted Jack Dorsey at a congressional hearing last week, he sounded flummoxed.

title: The Wall Street Power Lunch Is Back, With Martinis and Impunity
description: The day Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy  Sept. 15, 2008  the Grill Room was practically empty. Julian Niccolini, the maitre dhtel and a co-owner of the Four Seasons restaurant, was taking calls nonstop. The calls came from Wall Street executive assistants, canceling the reservations of the so-called Masters of the Universe who had suddenly become the Masters of Nothing.

title: Living In ... River Edge, N.J.
description: With impeccable streets, well-regarded schools and a quick commute to Manhattan, most residents say they dont miss having a proper downtown.

title: River Edge, N.J.: A Walkable Place With One Notable Shortcoming
description: Two years after settling into their new home in suburban River Edge, N.J., Becky and Joe Burns, both 43, are still asked by others in town, Which one of you is from here?

title: Migrants Expected Warm Welcome on Korean Resort Island. They Were Wrong.
description: JEJU, South Korea  A subtropical island famed for its turquoise seas, female divers and golf courses, Jeju has attracted South Korean honeymooners for decades. In recent months, however, the resort island has been receiving a new type of visitor  asylum seekers fleeing the catastrophe in Yemen.

title: Super Typhoon Mangkhut Heads Toward Philippines and China
description: HONG KONG  A super typhoon packing winds of up to 150 miles per hour is heading toward the Philippines, picking up speed over the Pacific on a route that also has Taiwan and the heavily populated southeastern coast of China in its sights.

title: Hurricane, Typhoon or Cyclone? Same Storm, Different Name
description: Hurricane Florence is bearing down on the eastern United States. A powerful typhoon, Jebi, tore through Japan last week, and another one, brewing in the Pacific, is headed for the Philippines and Taiwan. Earlier this year, Cyclone Mekunu killed more than 30 people in Yemen and Oman.

title: Regime Change or Stalemate?
description: On Sunday the Sweden Democrats, a right-wing party with roots in fascism, scored their highest share yet of the Swedish parliamentary vote  and the mandarins of Europe breathed a sigh of relief, because that higher-than-ever share was only 17.6 percent, and there had been fears that the cleaned-up fascists would reach 25 percent instead.
